steps.title: Grab a multimeter.
steps.content: Grab a multimeter. A multimeter is a black box of electronic circuitry used to test electrical wiring or devices. There is a large dial in the center of the multimeter where you can adjust the settings. The multimeter uses black (negative) and red (positive) leads to test electrical currency and resistance. These leads usually have metal clamps at the end of them. While the multimeter can seem daunting because of its many numbers and dials, you only need to use one setting for this test. [1] X Research source Analog meters may apply higher voltage to the circuit than the digital meter, so use them with care. The first reading you get from a digital multimeter may not be accurate, since the current can fluctuate. Digital multimeters have a difficult time measuring current that is constantly changing. [2] X Research source Because analog multimeters have a changing display, they can show you the current fluctuations. However, analog multimeters are less accurate overall. It is best to use a digital multimeter for this test. A digital multimeter shows the exact number result of the test. An analog multimeter is harder to read because every possible result is listed at the top. [3] X Research source If you are using an analog multimeter, make sure to choose one with at least 20k ohm/V sensitivity. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Set your multimeter to ohms.
steps.content: Set your multimeter to ohms. The ohms setting will be denoted by a shape that resembles an upside down horseshoe. There will be two long vertical lines containing the range of the ohms.

steps.title: Find resistance value of your multimeter.
steps.content: Find resistance value of your multimeter. Cross the two leads of the multimeter over each other and record the result. Make sure the metal clamps of the leads touch each other. If you are using a digital multimeter, then the reading will appear across the screen. Subtract this amount from the glow plug reading.

steps.title: Test the voltage of the battery.
steps.content: Test the voltage of the battery. Put your multimeter in DC Volt reading mode. Place the negative lead of your multimeter onto the negative terminal of the battery, and the positive lead onto the positive terminal. The reading should be close to 12.5 Volts when the car is off and close to 13 Volts when the car is running. If this is not the case, check your battery or alternator before proceeding. Glow plugs will not work correctly if they do not have the correct voltage running into them.

steps.title: Locate the glow plugs.
steps.content: Locate the glow plugs. Consult the shop manual of your vehicle to find the location of the glow plugs in the engine. This will vary based on the make and model of your vehicle.

steps.title: Remove the caps or connectors to the glow plugs.
steps.content: Remove the caps or connectors to the glow plugs. There is usually a cover or cap over the glow plugs. Remove the cover or cap in order to apply the multimeter clamps to the glow plugs. Look at the connector and pins for any signs of rust or corrosion and looseness. Take this opportunity to clean them.

steps.title: Clip the multimeter’s negative lead to a ground point in the engine.
steps.content: Clip the multimeter’s negative lead to a ground point in the engine. The main two ground points can be found by following the wire that leads from the negative battery terminal into the engine wall or following the wire that leads from the alternator into the engine wall. These wires are attached to bolts. Attach the negative lead onto one of these bolts for grounding. Consult your owner’s manual to find the exact locations of the ground points.

steps.title: Connect the positive lead of your multimeter to the top of the glow plug.
steps.content: Connect the positive lead of your multimeter to the top of the glow plug. If the multimeter's negative lead is still connected to the negative battery terminal, then you can leave it there.

steps.title: Evaluate the multimeter’s reading.
steps.content: Evaluate the multimeter’s reading. Refer to your shop manual to determine the test specs for your vehicle. Subtract the resistance value of your multimeter from the resistance value of your glow plug. For example, if your plug's resistance measured .9 ohms and your meter's resistance measured .2 ohms, the real reading for the plug is .7 ohms. [5] X Research source All the glow plugs in your engine should have similar readings. One glow plug with a higher resistance can affect your engine's performance--even if the plug is still good. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Replace the glow plugs.
steps.content: Replace the glow plugs. If one or more of the glow plugs is faulty, replace all of them. Never replace a single plug. [7] X Research source If the area around the glow plugs has dirt or buildup, clean it first. Some manufacturers have special tools to clean out the bore where the glow plugs are inserted into the cylinder head. These tools clean out carbon buildup in the area inside the combustion chamber or precharge chamber. The tool also cleans the threads that the glow plug screws into. This tool is sometimes called a "reamer." [8] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the glow plugs from your engine.
steps.content: Remove the glow plugs from your engine. Check your owner’s manual to locate the glow plugs and find the best way to remove them. This will vary based on the model and make of your vehicle.

steps.title: Set your multimeter to ohms.
steps.content: Set your multimeter to ohms. Use the lowest ohms setting. If the measurement of the glow plug is too high for the setting of the multimeter, then the plug is bad.

steps.title: Find resistance value of your multimeter.
steps.content: Find resistance value of your multimeter. Cross the two leads of the multimeter over each other and record the result. Subtract this amount from the glow plug reading.

steps.title: Place the negative lead of the multimeter onto the nut of the glow plug.
steps.content: Place the negative lead of the multimeter onto the nut of the glow plug. Make sure you do no not place the negative lead higher than the nut.

steps.title: Place the positive lead onto the tip of the glow plug.
steps.content: Place the positive lead onto the tip of the glow plug. The tip is exposed when you pull the glow plug cap off.

steps.title: Find the results on the multimeter.
steps.content: Find the results on the multimeter. Check your shop manual for your vehicle's test specs. Subtract the resistance value of your multimeter from the resistance value of your glow plug. For example, if your plug's resistance measured .9 ohms and your meter's resistance measured .2 ohms, the real reading for the plug is .7 ohms. All the glow plugs from your engine should have similar readings. One glow plug with a higher resistance can affect your engine's performance--even if the plug is still good. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Replace the glow plugs.
steps.content: Replace the glow plugs. If one or more of the glow plugs is faulty, replace all of them. Never replace a single plug. [10] X Research source
